body.p:
Bedford Trimble County
Kentucky
Jany 26th 1864
Sir

I have the satisfaction to return to you in behalf many friends of Trimble who had fines against them to return my, and their, thanks to you for extending clemency to them, but their is one friend yet whose fines Stand without clemency being extended to him and I know his case presents stronger grounds for foregiveness, than any other and that is the case of Mr William P. Adcock.

One case was for suffering gaming in his house, and another for Selling Liquor to Minors. I know that in each case, he was innocent for the men that gambled got a room and played without his knowledge for only five cents a game and of the Minors he was not aware of their being under age.

I am one of those who was an humble supporter of your election
and would be the last man to petition you to pardon indiscrimiately all offences; but in cases when you can exercise that humane power vested in you by organize law; I would justify you in it, and would be the last man to forsake you on that, but on the contrary would defend you in my humble way.
Man is but a poor creature at best and if he is ever Saved it will be though the medium of foregivness.
I hope you will excuse me for my importunities for my friends; but they knowing my nature apply to me to implore you and I cannot resist.

Very Respectfully and Humbly
Your friend & Obt Sevt
Silas Gatewood
See Adcocks Pet. & remit except fees & costs
